member.name: T:Unity.Entities.IComponentData
member.summary: This interface marks structs as 'unmanaged components' and classes as 'managed components'.
member.remarks: For more information, see the documentation on [components](xref:ecs-components).

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.IBufferElementData
member.summary: An interface for creating structs that can be stored in a .
member.remarks: See [Dynamic Buffers](xref:components-buffer-introducing) for additional information.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.InternalBufferCapacityAttribute
member.summary: Specifies the maximum number of elements to store inside a chunk.
member.remarks:
Use this attribute on the declaration of your IBufferElementData subtype:
[InternalBufferCapacity(10)] public struct FloatBufferElement : IBufferElementData { public float Value; }
All with this type of element store the specified number of elements inside the chunk along with other component types in the same archetype. When the number of elements in the buffer exceeds this limit, the entire buffer is moved outside the chunk.
[DefaultBufferCapacityNumerator](xref:Unity.Entities.TypeManager.DefaultBufferCapacityNumerator) defines the default number of elements.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.InternalBufferCapacityAttribute.Capacity
member.summary: The number of elements stored inside the chunk.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.InternalBufferCapacityAttribute.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: The number of elements stored inside the chunk.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.MaximumChunkCapacityAttribute
member.summary: Specifies the maximum number of components of a type that can be stored in the same chunk.
member.remarks:
Place this attribute on the declaration of a component, such as , to limit the number of entities with that component which can be stored in a single chunk. Note that the actual limit on the number of entities in a chunk can be smaller, based on the actual size of all the components in the same as the component defining this limit.
If an archetype contains more than one component type specifying a chunk capacity limit, then the lowest limit is used.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.MaximumChunkCapacityAttribute.Capacity
member.summary: The maximum number of entities having this component type in an .

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.MaximumChunkCapacityAttribute.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: The maximum number of entities having this component type in an .

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.ChunkSerializableAttribute
member.summary: States that a component type is serializable.
member.remarks:
By default, ECS does not support storing pointer types in chunks. Apply this attribute to a component declaration to allow the use of pointers as fields in the component.
Note that ECS does not perform any pre- or post-serialization processing to maintain pointer validity. When using this attribute, your code assumes responsibility for handling pointer serialization and deserialization.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.ISharedComponentData

member.remarks: For more information, see the documentation on [Shared components](xref:components-shared).

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.IEnableableComponent
member.summary: An interface for a component type which allows the component to be enabled and disabled at runtime without a structural change.
member.remarks: This interface is only valid when used in combination with or . While the extra overhead involved in processing enableable components is generally quite low, this interface should only be used on components that will actually be enabled/disabled by the application at relatively high frequency.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.Disabled
member.summary: Disables the entity.
member.remarks: By default, an ignores all entities that have this component. You can override this default behavior by setting the `EntityQueryOptions.IncludeDisabledEntities` flag of the object used to create the query.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.Prefab
member.summary: Marks the entity as a prefab, which implicitly disables the entity.
member.remarks: By default, an ignores all entities that have a Prefab component. You can override this default behavior by setting the EntityQueryOptions.IncludePrefab flag of the object used to create the query.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.Asset
member.summary: Marks the entity as an asset, which is used for the Export phase of GameObject conversion.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.LinkedEntityGroup
member.summary: The LinkedEntityGroup buffer makes the entity be the root of a set of connected entities.
member.remarks: Referenced Prefabs automatically add a LinkedEntityGroup with the complete child hierarchy. EntityManager.Instantiate uses LinkedEntityGroup to instantiate the whole set of entities automatically. EntityManager.SetEnabled uses LinkedEntityGroup to enable the whole set of entities.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.Simulate
member.summary: Enable simulation of an entity.
member.remarks: This component is added by default to all entities. Systems which needs to support simulating a subset of entities matching a specific query - such as prediction systems in netcode - need to include this component in their queries to make sure entities which are not supposed to be simulated at the moment are skipped.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.World.GetOrCreateSystem``1
member.summary: Retrieve the handle for the instance of a system of type from the current World. If the system does not exist in this World, it will first be created.
member.remarks: **Important:** This function creates a sync point if a system is created, which means that the EntityManager waits for all currently running Jobs to complete before creating the system, and no additional Jobs can start before the function is finished. A sync point can cause a drop in performance because the ECS framework may not be able to make use of the processing power of all available cores.
member.typeparam: The system type
member.returns: The handle for the instance of system type in this World. If the system does not exist in this World, it will first be created.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.World.GetOrCreateSystemManaged``1
member.summary: Retrieve the instance of a system of type from the current World. If the system does not exist in this World, it will first be created.
member.remarks:
**Important:** This function creates a sync point if a system is created, which means that the EntityManager waits for all currently running Jobs to complete before creating the system, and no additional Jobs can start before the function is finished. A sync point can cause a drop in performance because the ECS framework may not be able to make use of the processing power of all available cores.
**Note:** This system reference is not guaranteed to be safe to use. If the system or world is destroyed then the OnDestroy and cleanup functionality will have been called for this system.
If possible, using is preferred, and instead of public member data, component data is recommended for system level data that needs to be shared between systems or externally to them. This defines a data protocol for the system which is separated from the system functionality.
Private member data which is only used internally to the system is recommended.
Keep in mind using a managed reference for systems - encourages coupling of data and functionality - couples data to the system type with no direct path to decouple - does not provide lifetime or thread safety guarantees for data access - does not provide lifetime or thread safety guarantees for system access through the returned managed reference
member.typeparam: The system type
member.returns: The instance of system type in this World. If the system does not exist in this World, it will first be created.

member.param: The system types to create
The number of elements in the enumeration
The allocator to use to allocate the output system list
member.returns: A list of system instances

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.World.GetOrCreateSystemsAndLogException(System.Type[],Unity.Collections.AllocatorManager.AllocatorHandle)
member.summary: Creates systems from the list of types which aren't already created in the current world.
member.remarks:
This function creates systems in the order they are passed in, and ignores and validity. If errors are encountered either when creating the system or when calling OnCreate, a default will be returned for that system.
**Important:** This function creates a sync point if any systems are created, which means that the EntityManager waits for all currently running Jobs to complete before creating the systems, and no additional Jobs can start before the function is finished. A sync point can cause a drop in performance because the ECS framework may not be able to make use of the processing power of all available cores.
member.param: The system types to create, in the order in which they should be created.
The allocator to use to allocate the output system list
member.returns: A list of system instances

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.World.QuitUpdate
member.summary: Set this property to true to abort a world update after the next system update.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.World.CurrentGroupAllocators
member.summary: Retrieve current double rewindable allocator for this World.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.World.SetGroupAllocator(Unity.Collections.DoubleRewindableAllocators*)
member.summary: Push group allocator into a stack.
member.remarks: System groups use the group allocator to rewind memory at a different rate from the world update. To do this, use the rate manager's ShouldGroupUpdate(), when pushing time into world. You can also set the group allocator to replace the world's update allocator. When popping time out of the world, you can rewind the allocator, and if not world owned update the allocator, and then restore the old allocator back.
member.param: The group allocator to push into a stack.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.World.RestoreGroupAllocator(Unity.Collections.DoubleRewindableAllocators*)
member.summary: Pop group allocator out of the stack.
member.remarks: System group can make use of group allocator to rewind memory at a different rate from the world update. User can achieve this in rate manager's ShouldGroupUpdate(), when pushing time into world, user also set group allocator to replace world update allocator. When popping time out of the world, user rewinds the allocator if not world owned update allocator and then restore the old allocator back.
member.param: The group allocator to pop from the stack.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.World.Update
member.summary: Update the World's default system groups.
member.remarks:
The system group update order is: 1. 2. 3.
Generally this is not necessary within the context of a UnityEngine application; instead, use to insert these system groups into the UnityEngine player loop, where they'll be interleaved with existing UnityEngine updates.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.World.SystemStub
member.summary: This stub system is used to create instances of aspects when no SystemState is available (outside dot runtime). It is used by EntityManager.GetAspect and EntityManager.GetAspectRO which will be called from the editor.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.WorldExtensions
member.summary: Variants of World methods that support unmanaged systems (s)

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.WorldExtensions.CreateSystem``1(Unity.Entities.World)
member.summary: Create and return a handle for an instance of a system of type in this World.
member.remarks:
This can result in multiple instances of the same system in a single World, which is generally undesirable.
**Important:** This function creates a sync point, which means that the EntityManager waits for all currently running Jobs to complete before creating the system, and no additional Jobs can start before the function is finished. A sync point can cause a drop in performance because the ECS framework may not be able to make use of the processing power of all available cores.
member.param: The World
member.typeparam: The system type
member.returns: The new system instance's handle of system type in this World.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.WorldExtensions.GetExistingSystem``1(Unity.Entities.World)
member.summary: Return an existing handle for an instance of a system of type in this World.
member.typeparam: The system type
member.param: The World
member.returns: The existing system instance's handle of system type in this World. If no such instance exists, the method returns SystemHandle.Null.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.WorldExtensions.GetOrCreateSystem``1(Unity.Entities.World)
member.summary: Retrieve the handle for an instance of a system of type from the current World. If the system does not exist in this World, it will first be created.
member.remarks: **Important:** This function creates a sync point if a system is created, which means that the EntityManager waits for all currently running Jobs to complete before creating the system, and no additional Jobs can start before the function is finished. A sync point can cause a drop in performance because the ECS framework may not be able to make use of the processing power of all available cores.
member.typeparam: The system type
member.param: The World
member.returns: The instance's handle of system type in this World. If the system does not exist in this World, it will first be created.

member.summary: Obsolete. Use instead.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.RefRO`1.IsValid
member.summary: Property that returns true if the reference is valid, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.RefRO`1.ValueRO
member.summary: Returns a read-only reference to the component value itself.
member.remarks: This value is a reference to the actual component data. It is safe to use this field directly, e.g. "Data.Value.SomeField". It is also safe to make a copy of this value, e.g. "var myComponent = Data.Value". Keeping a ref ("ref var myref = Data.Value" is inherently unsafe as any structural change may invalidate this reference, and there is no way to detect this. It is safe to use this reference locally if you can guarantee that no structural changes will occur in between acquiring it and using it. Do not hold on to such a reference for any extended amount of time.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.AddDownloadService(Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDownloadService)
member.summary: Adds a download service. The priority of the service will be used to set the order. If there is another service with the same priority, the priority of the service added will be increased until it can be added. When added, OnAddedToDeliveryService will be called on the service. If there is a service with the same name, the existing service will be replaced with the passed in service.
member.param: The download service.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.AddLocationService(Unity.Entities.Content.ContentLocationService)
member.summary: Adds a location service. The priority of the service will be used to set the order. If there is another service with the same priority, the priority of the service added will be increased until it can be added. When added, OnAddedToDeliveryService will be called on the service.
member.param: The location service.

The results of the status inquiry. If the id refers to a set of requests, this array will contain multiple entries.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.CancelAllDeliveries
member.summary: Cancels all active downloads. This also marks all completed downloads as cancelled as well. This will force any previously completed downloads to restart.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.GetDeliveryStatus(Unity.Entities.Content.RemoteContentId@)
member.summary: Gets the delivery status of a remote id. If the id refers to a single delivery, the status returned will be for that id. If it refers to a set of deliveries, the status will be aggregated to the lowest value of the set.
member.param: The remote content id.
member.returns: The status of the delivery.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.DeliverContent(System.String,Unity.Entities.Hash128,System.Int64,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Starts the process of delivering content based on its location.
member.param: The url of the remote content.
The hash of the remote content. If not set, the cache will not be used.
The expected size of the remote content. If not set, accurate download progress is not available.
The crc of the content. If not set, the crc is not checked.
member.returns: The remote content id for the content that is downloaded. This id can be used to check the status of the download.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.DeliverContent(Unity.Entities.Content.RemoteContentLocation@)
member.summary: Starts the process of delivering content based on its location.
member.param: The location of the content.
member.returns: The generated remote content id for the location. This can be used to track the progress.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.CancelDelivery(Unity.Entities.Content.RemoteContentId@)
member.summary: Cancel an in progress download. This will remove the download state and attempt to cancel the download if it is still inprogress or queued. If the download has already completed, the cached data will not be removed.
member.param: The remote content id to cancel.
member.returns: False if the id is not known. True otherwise.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.ContentDeliveryService.DeliverContent(Unity.Entities.Content.RemoteContentId@)

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1
member.summary: Weak reference to an object. This allows control over when an object is loaded and unloaded.
member.typeparam: The type of UnityEngine.Object this reference points to.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.Id
member.summary: The reference Id.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.IsReferenceValid
member.summary: Returns true if the reference has a valid id. This does not imply that the referenced object is loaded.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.LoadingStatus
member.summary: Get the loading status of the referenced object.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.Result
member.summary: The value of the referenced object. This returns a valid object if IsLoaded is true.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.LoadAsync
member.summary: Directs the object to begin loading. This will increase the reference count for each call to the same id. Release must be called for each Load call to properly release resources.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.Release
member.summary: Releases the object. This will decrement the reference count of this object. When an objects reference count reaches 0, the archive file is released. The archive file is only unloaded when its reference count reaches zero, which will then release the archive it was loaded from. Archives will be unmounted when their reference count reaches 0.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.WaitForCompletion(System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait for object load in main thread. This will force synchronous loading and may cause performance issues.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait. If set to 0, the load will either complet or fail before returning.
member.returns: True if the load completes within the timeout.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectReference`1.ToString
member.summary: String conversion override.
member.returns: String representation of reference which includes type, guid and local id.

member.returns: The hash code of this reference.

member.remarks: By default, this loads the catalog from the StreamingAssets folder. However, if you've set the 'ENABLE_CONTENT_DELIVERY' define, this initiates the content delivery system and updates the content before loading the catalog.
member.param: The remote URL root for the content. Set null or leave empty, to load the catalog from the local StreamingAssets path.
Optional path for the local cache. Set null or leave empty to create a folder named 'ContentCache' in the device's Application.persistentDataPath.
Initial content set to download. 'all' is generally used to denote the entire content set.
Set to true, to use application command line arguments to override the passed in values.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Content.WeakObjectSceneReference.Release
member.summary: Releases the object. This will decrement the reference count of this object. When an objects reference count reaches 0, the archive file is released. The archive file is only unloaded when its reference count reaches zero, which will then release the archive it was loaded from. Archives will be unmounted when their reference count reaches 0.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.IAspect
member.summary: Base interface for Aspects, a higher level combination for components.
member.remarks: Implement IAspect on a struct with any number of fields. A field may use these attributes: [] Make the component optional. Field will be true if the component is present on the current entity. [] Make the component read-only when building an entity query that uses the aspect. The field will break the safety checks. Use instead.

member.returns: Returns the NativeList

member.remarks: Users should be extremely careful when accessing this field from job code. Specifically, multiple threads must not modify the same . The type is not thread-safe, and parallel writes will result in race conditions and unpredictable behavior.

member.summary: The index of the specified Entity within the entities in .

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.StorageInfoFromEntity
member.summary: Obsolete. Use instead.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityStorageInfoLookup
member.summary: A [NativeContainer] that provides access to information about how Entities are stored. .
member.remarks:
EntityStorageInfoLookup is a native container that provides access to information about how Entities are stored. You can use EntityStorageInfoLookup to look up data associated with one entity while iterating over a different set of entities.
To get a EntityStorageInfoLookup, call .
Pass a EntityStorageInfoLookup container to a job by defining a public field of the appropriate type in your IJob implementation. You can safely read from EntityStorageInfoLookup in any job, and the EntityStorageInfoLookup will never write data.
If you would like to access an entity's storage information outside of a job, consider using the methods instead, to avoid the overhead of creating a EntityStorageInfoLookup object.
[NativeContainer]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.LowLevel.Unsafe.NativeContainerAttribute [NativeContainerIsReadOnly]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.LowLevel.Unsafe.NativeContainerIsReadOnlyAttribute.html

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Serialization.SerializeUtility.SerializeWorldIntoYAML(Unity.Entities.EntityManager,System.IO.StreamWriter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Serialize the given World to a YAML file, for logging and analysis purpose
member.param: Entity Manager of the World to serialize
The stream we will write the data to

If true the binary data of each chunk section (header, component data of each entity) will be saved. This will increase the volume of data being written drastically, but you will be able to diff at the binary level
member.remarks: Analysing a serialized sub-scene for instance is not easy because the data is raw binary. It is even harder if we want to compare two distinct serialization of the same sub-scene. This method will allow us to save the data of a given World in YAML. Note that so far the data being saved is not totally complete, it will improve over time.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Serialization.SerializeUtility.GetSceneSectionEntity(System.Int32,Unity.Entities.EntityManager,Unity.Entities.EntityQuery@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the entity representing the scene section with the index passed in. If createIfMissing is true the section entity is created if it doesn't already exist. Metadata components added to this section entity will be serialized into the entity scene header. At runtime these components will be added to the scene section entities when the scene is resolved. Only struct IComponentData components without BlobAssetReferences or Entity members are supported.
member.param: The section index for which to get the scene section entity
The entity manager to which the entity belongs
The EntityQuery used to find the entity. Initially an null query should be passed in, the same query can the be passed in for subsequent calls to avoid recreating the query
If true the section entity is created if it doesn't already exist. If false Entity.Null is returned for missing section entities
member.returns: The entity representing the scene section

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.Serialization.DotsSerializationWriter.NodeHandle`1.WriteData(System.Void*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write data into the raw data section for this node
member.param: Source buffer
Length to write
member.remarks: This API can be called multiple times, it will write data sequentially. Notice that you can't call it multiple times before AND after creating children nodes (i.e. create this node A, write data for A, create child B, write data for A) for the reason the raw data section has to be a contiguous segment of data and writing data for other node would break this contiguity.

members.member:
Access the Writer Handle to perform stream based access.
The purpose of this object is to perform stream based writes to the node raw data and to mark the write sequence completed when is called.

member.summary: The is used to build a set of changes between two worlds.
member.remarks:
This class can be used to determine both forward and/or reverse changes between the worlds.
This class relies on the to uniquely identify entities, and expects that each entity will have a unique value for this component. If any duplicate values are encountered a will be thrown.
for tracking changes over time.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityDiffer.GatherComponentChangesReadOnlyData.UseReferentialEquivalence
member.summary: If set, components are not compared bit-wise. Bit-wise comparison implies that two components that have references to entities that have the same GUID but different indices/versions are different. Similarly blob asset references to blob assets that have the same hash but live at different addresses will be considered different as well. This is often not desirable. For these cases, it is more apt to check that GUIDs and hashes match.
This method returns all entity names for the given array of entityGuid components.
member.remarks: This method relies on the source buffers the entityGuids was built from. While this could technically be done while building the entityGuid set, it's a bit more isolated this way so we can remove it easily in the future.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityCommandBufferSystem
member.summary: A system that provides objects for other systems.
member.remarks:
Each system that uses the EntityCommandBuffer provided by a command buffer system must call to create its own command buffer instance. This buffer system executes each of these separate command buffers in the order that you created them. The commands are executed during this system's function.
When you write to a command buffer from a Job, you must add the of that Job to the buffer system's dependency list with .
If you write to a command buffer from a Job that runs in parallel (and this includes both and ), you must use the concurrent version of the command buffer ().
Executing the commands in an EntityCommandBuffer invokes the corresponding functions of the . Any structural change, such as adding or removing entities, adding or removing components from entities, or changing shared component values, creates a sync-point in your application. At a sync point, all Jobs accessing entity components must complete before new Jobs can start. Such sync points make it difficult for the Job scheduler to fully utilize available computing power. To avoid sync points, you should use as few entity command buffer systems as possible.
The default ECS code creates a setup with three main groups, , , and . Each of these main groups provides an existing EntityCommandBufferSystem executed at the start and the end of other, child systems.
Note that unused command buffers systems do not create sync points because there are no commands to execute and thus no structural changes created.
The EntityCommandBufferSystem class is abstract, so you must implement a subclass to create your own entity command buffer system. However, none of its methods are abstract, so you do not need to implement your own logic. Typically, you create an EntityCommandBufferSystem subclass to create a named buffer system for other systems to use and update it at an appropriate place in a custom setup.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityCommandBufferSystem.m_PendingBuffers
member.summary: List of command buffers that this system has allocated, which are played back and disposed of when the system updates.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityCommandBufferSystem.CreateCommandBuffer
member.summary: Creates an and adds it to this system's list of command buffers.
member.remarks:
This buffer system executes its list of command buffers during its function in the order you created the command buffers.
If you write to a command buffer in a Job, you must add the Job as a dependency of this system by calling . The dependency ensures that the buffer system waits for the Job to complete before executing the command buffer.
If you write to a command buffer from a parallel Job, such as or , you must use the concurrent version of the command buffer, provided by .
member.returns: A command buffer that will be executed by this system.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityCommandBufferSystem.AddJobHandleForProducer(Unity.Jobs.JobHandle)
member.summary: Adds the specified JobHandle to this system's list of dependencies.
member.remarks: When you write to an from a Job, you must add the of that Job to this 's input dependencies by calling this function. Otherwise, this system could attempt to execute the command buffer contents while the writing Job is still running, causing a race condition.
member.param: The JobHandle of a Job which this buffer system should wait for before playing back its pending command buffers.
member.example: The following example illustrates how to use one of the default s. The code selects all entities that have one custom component, in this case, `AsyncProcessInfo`, and processes each entity in the `Execute()` function of an Job. After processing, the Job uses a to remove the `ProcessInfo` component and add a `ProcessCompleteTag` component. Another system could use the `ProcessCompleteTag` to find entities that represent the end results of the process.

member.remarks: If you override this method, you should call `base.OnCreate()` to retain the default initialization logic.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.ComponentLookup`1
member.summary: A [NativeContainer] that provides access to all instances of components of type T, indexed by .
member.typeparam: The type of to access.
member.remarks:
ComponentLookup is a native container that provides array-like access to components of a specific type. You can use ComponentLookup to look up data associated with one entity while iterating over a different set of entities. For example, Unity.Transforms stores the object of parent entities in a Parent component and looks up the parent's LocalToWorld matrix using ComponentLookup<LocalToWorld> when calculating the world positions of child entities.
To get a ComponentLookup, call .
Pass a ComponentLookup container to a job by defining a public field of the appropriate type in your IJob implementation. You can safely read from ComponentLookup in any job, but by default, you cannot write to components in the container in parallel jobs (including , Entities.Foreach and ). If you know that two instances of a parallel job can never write to the same index in the container, you can disable the restriction on parallel writing by adding [NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute] to the ComponentLookup field definition in the job struct.
If you would like to access an entity's components outside of a job, consider using the methods and instead, to avoid the overhead of creating a ComponentLookup object.
[NativeContainer]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.LowLevel.Unsafe.NativeContainerAttribute [NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute.html

member.param: The system on which this type handle is cached.

members.member:
Retrieves the component associated with the specified , if it exists. Then reports if the instance still refers to a valid entity and that it has a component of type T.
The entity. /// The component of type T for the given entity, if it exists. True if the entity has a component of type T, and false if it does not.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentLookup`1.DidChange(Unity.Entities.Entity,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Reports whether any of IComponentData components of the type T, in the chunk containing the specified , could have changed.
member.remarks: Note that for efficiency, the change version applies to whole chunks not individual entities. The change version is incremented even when another job or system that has declared write access to a component does not actually change the component value.
member.param: The entity.
The version to compare. In a system, this parameter should be set to the current at the time the job is run or scheduled.
member.returns: True, if the version number stored in the chunk for this component is more recent than the version passed to the parameter.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentLookup`1.Item(Unity.Entities.Entity)
member.summary: Gets the instance of type T for the specified entity.
member.param: The entity.
member.returns: An type.
member.remarks:
Normally, you cannot write to components accessed using a ComponentLookup instance in a parallel Job. This restriction is in place because multiple threads could write to the same component, leading to a race condition and nondeterministic results. However, when you are certain that your algorithm cannot write to the same component from different threads, you can manually disable this safety check by putting the [NativeDisableParallelForRestrictions] attribute on the ComponentLookup field in the Job.
[NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute.html

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentLookup`1.Item(Unity.Entities.SystemHandle)
member.summary: Gets the instance of type T for the specified system's associated entity.
member.param: The system handle.
member.returns: An type.
member.remarks:
Normally, you cannot write to components accessed using a ComponentDataFromEntity instance in a parallel Job. This restriction is in place because multiple threads could write to the same component, leading to a race condition and nondeterministic results. However, when you are certain that your algorithm cannot write to the same component from different threads, you can manually disable this safety check by putting the [NativeDisableParallelForRestrictions] attribute on the ComponentDataFromEntity field in the Job.
[NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.NativeDisableParallelForRestrictionAttribute.html

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.DefaultWorldInitialization
member.summary: Utilities to help initialize the default ECS .

member.name: E:Unity.Entities.DefaultWorldInitialization.DefaultWorldInitialized
member.summary: Invoked after the default World is initialized.

member.name: E:Unity.Entities.DefaultWorldInitialization.DefaultWorldDestroyed
member.summary: Invoked after the Worlds are destroyed.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.DefaultWorldInitialization.CleanupWorldBeforeSceneLoad
member.summary: Destroys Editor World when entering Play Mode without Domain Reload. RuntimeInitializeOnLoadMethod is called before the new scene is loaded, before Awake and OnEnable of MonoBehaviour.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.DefaultWorldInitialization.RegisterUnloadOrPlayModeChangeShutdown
member.summary: Ensures the current World destruction on shutdown or when entering/exiting Play Mode or Domain Reload. 1) When switching to Play Mode Editor World (if created) has to be destroyed: - after the current scene objects are destroyed and OnDisable/Destroy are called, - before game scene is loaded and Awake/OnEnable are called. 2) When switching to Edit Mode Game World has to be destroyed: - after the current scene objects are destroyed and OnDisable/Destroy are called, - before backup scene is loaded and Awake/OnEnable are called. 3) When Unloading Domain (as well as Editor/Player exit) Editor or Game World has to be destroyed: - after OnDisable/OnBeforeSerialize are called, - before AppDomain.DomainUnload. Point 1) is covered by RuntimeInitializeOnLoadMethod attribute. For points 2) and 3) there are no entry point in the Unity API and they have to be handled by a proxy MonoBehaviour which in OnDisable can drive the World cleanup for both Exit Play Mode and Domain Unload.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.DefaultWorldInitialization.Initialize(System.String,System.Boolean)

member.param: The name of the world that will be created. Unless there is a custom bootstrap.
Editor worlds by default only include systems with [WorldSystemFilter(WorldSystemFilterFlags.Editor)]. If editorWorld is true, ICustomBootstrap will not be used.
member.returns: The initialized object.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.IRefCounted
member.summary: An interface for managed and unmanaged shared component types to inherit from. Whenever a IRefCounted shared component is added to a world, its Retain() method will be invoked. Similarly, when removed from a world, its Release() method will be invoked. This interface can be used to safely manage the lifetime of a shared component whose instance data is shared between multiple worlds.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.IRefCounted.Release
member.summary: Called when a world has the last instance of a IRefCounted type removed from it.

member.summary: BufferCapacity is by default calculated as DefaultBufferCapacityNumerator / sizeof(BufferElementDataType) thus for a 1 byte component, the maximum number of elements possible to be stored in chunk memory before the buffer is allocated separately from chunk data, is DefaultBufferCapacityNumerator elements. member.name: M:Unity.Entities.TypeManager.CalculateAlignmentInChunk(System.Int32)
member.summary: Our alignment calculations for types are taken from the perspective of the alignment of the type _specifically_ when stored in chunk memory. This means a type's natural alignment may not match the AlignmentInChunk value. Our current scheme is such that an alignment of 'MaximumSupportedAlignment' is assumed unless the size of the type is smaller than 'MaximumSupportedAlignment' and is a power of 2. In such cases we use the type size directly, thus if you have a type that naturally aligns to 4 bytes and has a size of 8, the AlignmentInChunk will be 8 as long as 8 is less than 'MaximumSupportedAlignment'.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.Enabled
member.summary: Controls whether this system executes when its OnUpdate function is called.
member.value: True, if the system is enabled.
member.remarks: The Enabled property is intended for debugging so that you can easily turn on and off systems from the Entity Debugger window. A system with Enabled set to false will not update, even if its function returns true.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.EntityQueries
member.summary: The query objects cached by this system.
member.remarks: A system caches any queries it implicitly creates through the IJob interfaces or , that you create explicitly by calling , or that you add to the system as a required query with . Implicit queries may be created lazily and not exist before a system has run for the first time.
member.value: A read-only array of the cached objects.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.GlobalSystemVersion
member.summary: The current change version number in this .
member.remarks: The system updates the component version numbers inside any instances that this system accesses with write permissions to this value.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.LastSystemVersion
member.summary: The current version of this system.
member.remarks:
LastSystemVersion is updated to match the whenever a system runs.
When you use or , LastSystemVersion provides the basis for determining whether a component could have changed since the last time the system ran.
When a system accesses a component and has write permission, it updates the change version of that component type to the current value of LastSystemVersion. The system updates the component type's version whether or not it actually modifies data in any instances of the component type -- this is one reason why you should specify read-only access to components whenever possible.
For efficiency, ECS tracks the change version of component types by chunks, not by individual entities. If a system updates the component of a given type for any entity in a chunk, then ECS assumes that the components of all entities in that chunk could have been changed. Change filtering allows you to save processing time by skipping all entities in an unchanged chunk, but does not support skipping individual entities in a chunk that does contain changes.
member.value: The the last time this system ran.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.EntityManager
member.summary: The EntityManager object of the in which this system exists.
member.value: The EntityManager for this system.

member.value: The World of this system.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.OnCreate
member.summary: Called when this system is created.
member.remarks:
Implement an OnCreate() function to set up system resources when it is created.
OnCreate is invoked before the the first time and OnUpdate are invoked.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.OnStartRunning
member.summary: Called before the first call to OnUpdate and when a system resumes updating after being stopped or disabled.
member.remarks: If the objects defined for a system do not match any existing entities then the system skips updates until a successful match is found. Likewise, if you set to false, then the system stops running. In both cases, is called when a running system stops updating; OnStartRunning is called when it starts updating again.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.OnStopRunning
member.summary: Called when this system stops running because no entities match the system's objects or because you change the system property to false.
member.remarks: If the objects defined for a system do not match any existing entities then the system skips updating until a successful match is found. Likewise, if you set to false, then the system stops running. In both cases, OnStopRunning is called when a running system stops updating; is called when it starts updating again.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.OnDestroy
member.summary: Called when this system is destroyed.
member.remarks: Systems are destroyed when the application shuts down, the World is destroyed, or you call . In the Unity Editor, system destruction occurs when you exit Play Mode and when scripts are reloaded.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.Update
member.summary: Executes the system immediately.
member.remarks: The exact behavior is determined by this system's specific subclass.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.ShouldRunSystem
member.summary: Reports whether this system satisfies the criteria to update. This function is used internally to determine whether the system's OnUpdate function can be skipped.
member.remarks:
By default, systems will invoke OnUpdate every frame.
If a system calls or in OnCreate, it will only update if all of its required components exist and required queries match existing chunks. This check uses [IsEmptyIgnoreFilter], so the queries may still be empty if they use filters or [Enableable Components].
If a system has the it will update if any EntityQuery it uses match existing chunks. This check also uses [IsEmptyIgnoreFilter], so all queries may still be empty if they use filters or [Enableable Components].
Note: Other factors might prevent a system from updating, even if this method returns true. For example, a system will not be updated if its [Enabled] property is false.
[IsEmptyIgnoreFilter]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.IsEmptyIgnoreFilter [Enableable Components]: xref:Unity.Entities.IEnableableComponent [Enabled]: xref:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.Enabled
member.returns: True if the system should be updated, or false if not.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.RequireForUpdate(Unity.Entities.EntityQuery)
member.summary: Adds a query that must match entities for the system to run. You can add multiple required queries to a system; all of them must match at least one entity for the system to run.
member.param: A query that must match entities this frame in order for this system to run.
member.remarks: Any queries added through RequireForUpdate override all other queries cached by this system. In other words, if any required query does not find matching entities, the update is skipped even if another query created for the system (either explicitly or implicitly) does match entities and vice versa.
Note that query filters are ignored so for components that implement this method ignores whether the component is enabled or not, it only checks whether it exists.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.RequireAnyForUpdate(Unity.Entities.EntityQuery[])
member.summary: Provide a set of queries, one of which must match entities for the system to run.
member.param: A set of queries, one of which must match entities this frame in order for this system to run.
member.remarks:
This method can only be called from a system's OnCreate method.
You can call this method multiple times from the same system to add multiple sets of required queries. Each set must have at least one query that matches an entity for the system to run.
Any queries added through RequireAnyForUpdate and [RequireForUpdate] override all other queries created by this system for the purposes of deciding whether to update. In other words, if any set of required queries does not find matching entities, the update is skipped even if another query created for the system (either explicitly or implicitly) does match entities and vice versa.
[EntityQueries]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery [enableable components]: xref:T:Unity.Entities.IEnableableComponent

Any queries added through RequireAnyForUpdate and [RequireForUpdate] override all other queries created by this system for the purposes of deciding whether to update. In other words, if any set of required queries does not find matching entities, the update is skipped even if another query created for the system (either explicitly or implicitly) does match entities and vice versa.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI
member.summary: Giving quick and consistent access to buffers, components, time, enumeration, singletons and more. This includes any , , , and . Suggested usage is: ```cs using static Unity.Entities.SystemAPI; [...] partial struct SomeJob : IJobEntity { void Execute(ref EcsTestData e1) => e1.value += Time.deltaTime; } ```

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI.QueryBuilder
member.summary: Gives a fluent API for constructing s similar to the . This API statically constructs the query as part of the system, and creates the query in the system's OnCreate. Calling this method should allow the construction of EntityQueries with almost no run-time performance overhead."

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI.GetComponent``1(Unity.Entities.Entity)
member.summary: Look up the value of a component for an entity.
member.param: The entity.
member.typeparam: The type of component to retrieve.
member.returns: A struct of type T containing the component value.
member.remarks:
Use this method to look up data in another entity using its object. For example, if you have a component that contains an Entity field, you can look up the component data for the referenced entity using this method.
When iterating over a set of entities via or , do not use this method to access data of the current entity in the set. This function is much slower than accessing the data directly (by passing the component containing the data to your lambda iteration function as a parameter).
When you call this method it gets replaced with component access methods through .
This lookup method results in a slower, indirect memory access. When possible, organize your data to minimize the need for indirect lookups.
member.exception: Thrown if the component type has no fields.
member.remarks: Not working in IJobEntity, Utility methods, and Aspects

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI.SetComponent``1(Unity.Entities.Entity,``0)
member.summary: Sets the value of a component of an entity.
member.param: The entity.
The data to set.
member.typeparam: The component type.
member.remarks:
Use this method to look up and set data in another entity using its object. For example, if you have a component that contains an Entity field, you can update the component data for the referenced entity using this method.
When iterating over a set of entities via or , do not use this method to update data of the current entity in the set. This function is much slower than accessing the data directly (by passing the component containing the data to your lambda iteration function as a parameter).
When you call this method gets replaced with component access methods through .
In both cases, this lookup method results in a slower, indirect memory access. When possible, organize your data to minimize the need for indirect lookups.
member.exception: Thrown if the component type has no fields.
member.remarks: Not working in IJobEntity, Utility methods, and Aspects

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI.HasComponent``1(Unity.Entities.Entity)
member.summary: Checks whether an entity has a specific type of component.
member.param: The Entity object.
member.typeparam: The data type of the component.
member.remarks:
Always returns false for an entity that has been destroyed.
Use this method to check if another entity has a given type of component using its object. For example, if you have a component that contains an Entity field, you can check whether the referenced entity has a specific type of component using this method. (Entities in the set always have required components, so you dont need to check for them.)
When iterating over a set of entities via or , avoid using this method with the current entity in the set. It is generally faster to change your entity query methods to avoid optional components; this may require a different construction to handle each combination of optional and non-optional components.
When you call this method this method gets replaced with component access methods through a cached .
This lookup method results in a slower, indirect memory access. When possible, organize your data to minimize the need for indirect lookups.
member.returns: True, if the specified entity has the component.
member.remarks: Not working in IJobEntity, Utility methods, and Aspects

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI.ManagedAPI.GetComponent``1(Unity.Entities.Entity)
member.summary: Look up the value of a component for an entity.
member.param: The entity.
member.typeparam: The type of component to retrieve.
member.returns: A struct of type T containing the component value.
member.remarks:
Use this method to look up data in another entity using its object. For example, if you have a component that contains an Entity field, you can look up the component data for the referenced entity using this method.
When iterating over a set of entities via or , do not use this method to access data of the current entity in the set. This function is much slower than accessing the data directly (by passing the component containing the data to your lambda iteration function as a parameter).
When you call this method gets replaced with component access methods through .
This lookup method results in a slower, indirect memory access. When possible, organize your data to minimize the need for indirect lookups.
member.exception: Thrown if the component type has no fields.
member.remarks: Not working in Entities.ForEach, IJobEntity, Utility methods, and Aspects

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemAPI.ManagedAPI.HasComponent``1(Unity.Entities.Entity)
member.summary: Checks whether an entity has a specific type of component.
member.param: The Entity object.
member.typeparam: The data type of the component.
member.remarks:
Always returns false for an entity that has been destroyed.
Use this method to check if another entity has a given type of component using its object. For example, if you have a component that contains an Entity field, you can check whether the referenced entity has a specific type of component using this method. (Entities in the set always have required components, so you dont need to check for them.)
When iterating over a set of entities via or , avoid using this method with the current entity in the set. It is generally faster to change your entity query methods to avoid optional components; this may require a different construction to handle each combination of optional and non-optional components.
When you call this method this method gets replaced with component access methods through a cached .
This lookup method results in a slower, indirect memory access. When possible, organize your data to minimize the need for indirect lookups.
member.returns: True, if the specified entity has the component.
member.remarks: Not working in Entities.ForEach, IJobEntity, Utility methods, and Aspects

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityQueryImpl.SyncFilterTypes
member.summary: Waits for any running jobs to complete which could affect which chunks/entities match this query.
member.remarks: If the query has an active change filter, this includes jobs writing to any types whose change version is being tracked. If the query includes any enableable components, this includes job writing to any of these types. It also includes a safety check to ensure that no unregistered jobs are writing to enableable types.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions
member.summary: Parameters used to configure the the execution of the differ.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions.None
member.summary: Shortcut for "no options required".

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions.IncludeForwardChangeSet
member.summary: If set; the resulting will include the forward change set.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions.IncludeReverseChangeSet
member.summary:
If set; the resulting will include the reverse change set.
This can be applied to the world to reverse the changes (i.e. undo).

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions.FastForwardShadowWorld
member.summary: If set; the shadow world will be updated with the latest changes.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions.ClearMissingReferences
member.summary:
If set; all references to destroyed or missing entities will be set to Entity.Null before computing changes.
When applying a change this is needed to patch references to restored entities (they were destroyed but are being brought back by the change set).
member.remarks: Performance scales with the total number of entities with the component in the source world.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityManagerDifferOptions.ValidateUniqueEntityGuid
member.summary: If this flag is set; the entire world is checks for duplicate components.
member.remarks: Performance scales with the number of created entities in the source world with the component.

members.member:
If set, components are not compared bit-wise. Bit-wise comparison implies that two components that have references to entities that have the same GUID but different indices/versions are different. Similarly blob asset references to blob assets that have the same hash but live at different addresses will be considered different as well. This is often not desirable. For these cases, it is more apt to check that GUIDs and hashes match.
/// This makes comparing components potentially more expensive.

member.summary: The default set of options used by the

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityDataAccess.CreateEntity(Unity.Entities.SystemHandle@)
member.summary: Creates an entity with no components.
member.remarks:
Creates the entity in the first available chunk with the archetype having no components.
**Important:** This function creates a sync point, which means that the EntityManager waits for all currently running Jobs to complete before creating the entity and no additional Jobs can start before the function is finished. A sync point can cause a drop in performance because the ECS framework may not be able to make use of the processing power of all available cores.
member.returns: The Entity object that you can use to access the entity.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.DisableAutoCreationAttribute
member.summary: Prevents a system from being automatically created and run.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags
member.summary: For internal use only.
member.remarks: Defines where internal Unity systems should be created. The existence of these flags and the specialized Worlds they represent are subject to change.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.Default
member.summary: When specifying the Default flag on a [WorldSystemFilter] the flag will be removed and expand to what was specified as ChildDefaultFilterFlags by the group the system is in. This means the Default flag will never be set when querying a system for its flags. If the system does not have a [UpdateInGroup] the system will be in the SimulationSystemGroup and get the ChildDefaultFilterFlags from that group. When creating a world - or calling GetSystems directly - default expands to LocalSimulation | Presentation to create a standard single player world.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.Disabled
member.summary: Systems explicitly disabled via the [DisableAutoCreation] attribute are by default placed in this world.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.EntitySceneOptimizations
member.summary: A specialized World created for optimizing scene rendering.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.ProcessAfterLoad
member.summary: A specialized World created for processing a scene after load.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.Editor
member.summary: The main World created when running in the Editor. Example: Editor LiveConversion system

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.BakingSystem
member.summary: Baking systems running after the BakingSystem system responsible from baking GameObjects to entities.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.LocalSimulation
member.summary: Worlds using local simulation, without any multiplayer client / server support.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.ServerSimulation
member.summary: Worlds using server simulation.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.ClientSimulation
member.summary: Worlds using client simulation.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.ThinClientSimulation
member.summary: Worlds using thin client simulation. A thin client is a client running the bare minimum set of systems to connect to and communicate with a server. It does not run the full simulation and cannot generally present the simulation state.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.Presentation
member.summary: Worlds presenting a rendered world.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.Streaming

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.WorldSystemFilterFlags.All

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityQueryDesc
member.summary: Describes a query to find archetypes in terms of required, optional, and excluded components.
member.remarks:
Define an EntityQueryDesc object to describe complex queries. Inside a system, pass an EntityQueryDesc object to to create the .
A query description combines the component types you specify in `All`, `Any`, and `None` sets according to the following rules:
* All - Includes archetypes that have every component in this set * Any - Includes archetypes that have at least one component in this set * None - Excludes archetypes that have any component in this set, but includes entities which have the component disabled. * Disabled - Includes archetypes that have every component in this set, but only matches entities where the component is disabled. * Absent - Excludes archetypes that have any component in this set.
For example, given entities with the following components:
* Player has components: ObjectPosition, ObjectRotation, Player * Enemy1 has components: ObjectPosition, ObjectRotation, Melee * Enemy2 has components: ObjectPosition, ObjectRotation, Ranger
The query description below matches all of the archetypes that: have any of [Melee or Ranger], AND have none of [Player], AND have all of [ObjectPosition and ObjectRotation]
In other words, the query created from this description selects the Enemy1 and Enemy2 entities, but not the Player entity.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityQueryDesc.Any
member.summary: Include archetypes that contain at least one (but possibly more) of the component types in the Any list.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityQueryDesc.None
member.summary: Include archetypes that do not contain these component types. For enableable component types, archetypes with these components will still be matched by the query, but only for entities with these components disabled.
member.remarks: Effectively, this list means "absent, or present (but disabled)".

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityQueryOptions.IgnoreComponentEnabledState
member.summary: The query will match all entities in all the query's matching archetypes, regardless of whether any enableable components on those entities are enabled or disabled.
member.remarks: Specifically: - Entities with all required enableable components will be matched, even if the components are disabled. - Entities with any optional enableable components will be matched, even if the components are disabled. - Entities with any excluded enableable component will be matched, even if the components are enabled. - Entities missing a required component will NOT be matched; their archetype is not in the potentially matching set. - Entities missing all the optional components will NOT be matched; their archetype is not in the potentially matching set.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityQueryMask
member.summary: Provides an efficient test of whether a specific archetype is included in the set of archetypes matched by an EntityQuery.
member.remarks:
Use a query mask to quickly identify whether an entity's archetype would be matched by an EntityQuery.
You can create up to 1024 unique EntityQueryMasks in an application. Note that EntityQueryMask only filters by Archetype. It doesn't support EntityQuery shared component, change filtering, or enableable components.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery
member.summary: Use an EntityQuery object to select entities with components that meet specific requirements.
member.remarks:
An entity query defines the set of component types that an [archetype] must contain in order for its chunks and entities to be selected and specifies whether the components accessed through the query are read-only or read-write.
For simple queries, you can create an EntityQuery based on an array of component types. The following example defines a EntityQuery that finds all entities with both Rotation and RotationSpeed components.
The query uses [ComponentType.ReadOnly] instead of the simpler `typeof` expression to designate that the system does not write to RotationSpeed. Always specify read-only when possible, since there are fewer constraints on read-only access to data, which can help the Job scheduler execute your Jobs more efficiently.
For more complex queries, you can use an object to create the entity query. A query description provides a flexible query mechanism to specify which archetypes to select based on the following sets of components:
* `All` = All component types in this array must exist in the archetype * `Any` = At least one of the component types in this array must exist in the archetype * `None` = None of the component types in this array can exist in the archetype
For example, the following query includes archetypes containing Rotation and RotationSpeed components, but excludes any archetypes containing a Static component:
**Note:** Do not include completely optional components in the query description. To handle optional components, use and the [ArchetypeChunk.Has()] method to determine whether a chunk contains the optional component or not. Since all entities within the same chunk have the same components, you only need to check whether an optional component exists once per chunk -- not once per entity.
Within a system class, use the [ComponentSystemBase.GetEntityQuery()] function to get a EntityQuery instance.
You can filter entities based on whether they have [changed] or whether they have a specific value for a [shared component]. Once you have created an EntityQuery object, you can [reset] and change the filter settings, but you cannot modify the base query.
Use an EntityQuery for the following purposes:
* To get a [native array] of a the values for a specific type for all entities matching the query * To get an [native array] of the objects matching the query * To schedule an job * To control whether a system updates using [ComponentSystemBase.RequireForUpdate(query)]
Note that [Entities.ForEach] defines an entity query implicitly based on the methods you call. You can access this implicit EntityQuery object using [Entities.WithStoreEntityQueryInField]. However, you cannot create an [Entities.ForEach] construction based on an existing EntityQuery object.
[Entities.ForEach]: xref:Unity.Entities.SystemBase.Entities [Entities.WithStoreEntityQueryInField]: xref:Unity.Entities.SystemBase.Entities [ComponentSystemBase.GetEntityQuery()]: xref:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.GetEntityQuery* [ComponentType.ReadOnly]: xref:Unity.Entities.ComponentType.ReadOnly``1 [ComponentSystemBase.RequireForUpdate()]: xref:Unity.Entities.ComponentSystemBase.RequireForUpdate(Unity.Entities.EntityQuery) [ArchetypeChunk.Has()]: xref:Unity.Entities.ArchetypeChunk.Has``1(Unity.Entities.ComponentTypeHandle{``0}) [archetype]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityArchetype [changed]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.SetChangedVersionFilter* [shared component]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.SetSharedComponentFilter* [reset]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.ResetFilter* [native array]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Collections.NativeArray_1.html

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.CalculateFilteredChunkIndexArray(Unity.Collections.Allocator)
member.summary: Generates an array which gives the index of each chunk relative to the set of chunks that currently match the query, after taking all active filtering into account.
member.param: The allocator used to allocate the output array.
member.returns: An array of integers, where array[N] is the index of chunk N among the list of chunks that match this query, once all chunk- and entity-level filtering has been applied. If chunk N is filtered out of the query, array[N] will be -1. The size of this array is given by .
member.remarks:
Note that the chunk index used to access the output array's elements should be relative to the full, unfiltered list of chunks matched by this query. Most commonly, this is the chunkIndex parameter available within . For queries with no chunk filtering and no enableable components, array[N] will equal N.
This function will automatically block until any running jobs which could affect its output have completed. For a non-blocking implementation, use .

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.GetIndexInEntityQuery(Unity.Entities.TypeIndex)
member.summary:
Index of a ComponentType in this EntityQuery's RequiredComponents list. For example, you have a EntityQuery that requires these ComponentTypes: ObjectPosition, ObjectVelocity, and Color.
These are their type indices (according to the TypeManager): Position.TypeIndex == 3 Velocity.TypeIndex == 5 Color.TypeIndex == 17
RequiredComponents: [Position -> Velocity -> Color] (a linked list) Given Velocity's TypeIndex (5), the return value would be 1, since Velocity is in slot 1 of RequiredComponents.
member.param: Index of a ComponentType in the TypeManager
member.returns: An index into RequiredComponents.

member.summary: Sets the value of a singleton component. Note that if querying a singleton component from a system-associated entity, the query must include either EntityQueryOptions.IncludeSystems or the SystemInstance component.
member.remarks:
For a component to be a singleton, there can be only one instance of that component that satisfies this query.
**Note:** singletons are otherwise normal entities. The EntityQuery and singleton functions add checks that you have not created two instances of a type that can be accessed by this singleton query, but other APIs do not prevent such accidental creation.
To create a singleton, create an entity with the singleton component.
For example, if you had a component defined as:
You could create a singleton as follows:
To update the singleton component after creation, you can use an EntityQuery object that selects the singleton entity and call this `SetSingleton()` function:
You can set and get the singleton value from a system: see and .
member.param: An instance of type T containing the values to set.
member.typeparam: The component type.
member.exception: Thrown if more than one instance of this component type exists in the world or the component type appears in more than one archetype.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.SetEnabledBitsOnAllChunks``1(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets or clears the "is enabled" bit for the provided component on all entities in all chunks matched by the query.
member.typeparam: The component type which should be enabled or disabled on all matching chunks. This type must be included in the query's required types, and must implement .
member.param: If true, the component will be enabled on all entities in all matching chunks. Otherwise, the component will be disabled on all components in all chunks.
member.remarks: The current value of the bits are ignored; this function will enable disabled components on entities, even if the component being disabled would cause the entity to not match the query. If any jobs are currently running which read or write the target component, this function will block until they complete before performing the requested operation.

member.name: T:Unity.Entities.EntityRemapUtility.HasRefResult
member.summary: Specifies if a System.Type has any or references in its hierarchy.
member.remarks:
This enum is returned by which recursively traverses a System.Type and its fields to find entity or blob asset references.
In some cases Unity cannot find all the Entity/Blob references within a type. For example, if the type is polymorphic and non-sealed, or if the type hierarchy is deep, making it too expensive to be worth inspecting it exhaustively. In this cases, the value specifies that although no actual reference was found, the type cannot be treated as a type which definitely does not have any references during serialization.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityRemapUtility.HasRefResult.NoRef
member.summary: The System.Type does not have any References within the entire hierarchy.

member.name: F:Unity.Entities.EntityRemapUtility.HasRefResult.MayHaveRef
member.summary: The System.Type might have References.
member.remarks:
Cases where we can't say with certainty if the type contains any references include if there is a polymorphic non-sealed type, or if the type hierarchy is deeper than the maximum specified recursion depth.
This value can be handled while validating the data for serialization.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.UnsafeChunkCache.MoveNextChunk(System.Int32@,Unity.Entities.ArchetypeChunk@,System.Int32@,System.Byte@,Unity.Burst.Intrinsics.v128@)
member.summary: Advance to the next non-empty, non-filtered chunk in the cache, if possible.
member.param: The index of the current chunk in the iteration. Calling this function will increment this index. The caller should initialize this value to -1 before the first call.
If the function is successful, the next chunk in the iteration is stored here.
If the function is successful, the number of entities in is stored here. Note that this count includes all entities in the chunk; for a count of the enabled entities, use on the mask.

When the function returns, a non-zero value here means that at least one entity in the chunk is disabled according to the requirements of this . In this case, the contents of the mask should be used to determine which entities match the query.

If a valid chunk is returned and at least one entity is disabled for the purposes of this EntityQuery, the combined mask of all entities in the chunk will be stored here. The contents of this parameter are only valid if is non-zero when the function returns.
member.returns: True if the next chunk was found. False if the end of the cached chunk list was reached (in which case, , and will be be default-initialized, and will be undefined).

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.SystemState.GlobalSystemVersion
member.summary: The current change version number in this .
member.remarks: The system updates the component version numbers inside any instances that this system accesses with write permissions to this value.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.SystemState.LastSystemVersion
member.summary: The current version of this system.
member.remarks:
LastSystemVersion is updated to match the whenever a system runs.
When you use or , LastSystemVersion provides the basis for determining whether a component could have changed since the last time the system ran.
When a system accesses a component and has write permission, it updates the change version of that component type to the current value of LastSystemVersion. The system updates the component type's version whether or not it actually modifies data in any instances of the component type -- this is one reason why you should specify read-only access to components whenever possible.
For efficiency, ECS tracks the change version of component types by chunks, not by individual entities. If a system updates the component of a given type for any entity in a chunk, then ECS assumes that the components of all entities in that chunk could have been changed. Change filtering allows you to save processing time by skipping all entities in an unchanged chunk, but does not support skipping individual entities in a chunk that does contain changes.
member.value: The the last time this system ran.

member.name: P:Unity.Entities.SystemState.Dependency
member.summary: The ECS-related data dependencies of the system.
member.remarks:
Before or , the Dependency property represents the combined job handles of any job that writes to the same components that the current system reads -- or reads the same components that the current system writes to.
The [JobHandle] objects of any jobs scheduled with explicit dependencies are not combined with the systems Dependency property. You must set the Dependency property manually to make sure that later systems receive the correct job dependencies.
[JobHandle]: https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Unity.Jobs.JobHandle.html

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemState.CompleteDependency
member.summary: Completes combined job handles registered with this system. See for more information.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemState.ShouldRunSystem
member.summary: Reports whether this system satisfies the criteria to update. This function is used internally to determine whether the system's OnUpdate function can be skipped.
member.remarks:
By default, systems will invoke OnUpdate every frame.
If a system calls or in OnCreate, it will only update if all of its required components exist and required queries match existing chunks. This check uses [IsEmptyIgnoreFilter], so the queries may still be empty if they use filters or [Enableable Components].
If a system has the it will update if any EntityQuery it uses match existing chunks. This check also uses [IsEmptyIgnoreFilter], so all queries may still be empty if they use filters or [Enableable Components].
Note: Other factors might prevent a system from updating, even if this method returns true. For example, a system will not be updated if its [Enabled] property is false.
[IsEmptyIgnoreFilter]: xref:Unity.Entities.EntityQuery.IsEmptyIgnoreFilter [Enableable Components]: xref:Unity.Entities.IEnableableComponent [Enabled]: xref:Unity.Entities.SystemState.Enabled
member.returns: True if the system should be updated, or false if not.

member.name: M:Unity.Entities.SystemState.RequireForUpdate(Unity.Entities.EntityQuery)
member.summary: Adds a query that must return entities for the system to run. You can add multiple required queries to a system; all of them must match at least one entity for the system to run.
member.param: A query that must match entities this frame in order for this system to run.
member.remarks:
Any queries added through RequireForUpdate override all other queries cached by this system. In other words, if any required query does not find matching entities, the update is skipped even if another query created for the system (either explicitly or implicitly) does match entities and vice versa.
Note that for components that implement this method ignores whether the component is enabled or not, it only checks whether it exists. It also ignores any other filters placed

Any queries added through RequireForUpdate override all other queries cached by this system.
